title: WHO FED X???? SHUT UP!
body:
Please stop asking, "WHO FED X?" in the middle of a game. He's fed, does it help your team to know who fed him? Does it make him not fed? Does it really matter who fed him? I mean he's fed. The worst part is people who ask it most of the time ask it when it is really obvious.

Example:

Shen Top 2-0-1
J4 JG 3-1-7
**{{champion:55}}  Mid 1-9-2**
Morgana Supp 0-1-7
Jinx ADC 4-2-1

**Enemy {{champion:238}}  12-0-3**

**"WHO FED ZED?**

Do you really have to ask? And what's even worse is that this question usually is a start to a blame game that pretty much screws up teamwork and costs your team the game. In this example, 85% of the time what follows that question is everyone answering, "Kat," and then Kat blaming other people and getting toxic and leading to an argument. If this is not a bannable offense, it better become one. This is basically the Blame Game. Again, if he's fed, how does it help knowing who did it?

replies.body:
They just say that because they're mad. Logic goes out the window when some people get mad. A lot of times people say things like this to try to get the offender (Kat in your example) to fess up and admit fault. It never ends well.

But honestly, the blame game isn't what's really costing you the game if Zed is 12-0-3 and kat is 1-9-2. Zed is rather difficult to play, and if he did that well he's probably a smurf.

"Zed is rather difficult to play"

As much as I want to agree, I have never seen any challenge in his mechanics other than messing up when you warp to shadows. Everything is quite simple in my opinion.

> [{quoted}](name=CataclysmG,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=24pVobPn,comment-id=00000003,timestamp=2015-07-01T20:29:25.549+0000)
>
> "Zed is rather difficult to play"
> 
> As much as I want to agree, I have never seen any challenge in his mechanics other than messing up when you warp to shadows. Everything is quite simple in my opinion.

Landing the Qs of both you and your shadow, landing both Ws, making sure you can autoattack after / before getting these spells off, dodging any CC once you teleport in, ensuring good shadow placement for escape / chasing. 

I mean, it's not rocket science, but when you compare it to most champs (annie or kayle...) he's far more difficult to play than most.

To play him perfectly is a lot harder, mechanically, than some champs.  But realistically, he has one of the easiest laning phases in the game.  And one of the easiest kills at 6.  I think that offsets the mechanical difficulty of his ideal combo.  Pretty easy champ to do well with. 

I agree with OP though.  Attitude can be everything in soloQ.

Laning is only part of the game though. Zed's pretty hard to play beyond that. In late game fights you need to keep track of who has Zhonyas and QSS, how to still kill them if they have these items, who has CC that can kill you, when to jump in, can I get out alive and if not, would it be worth the trade? Splitpush is also difficult because you need good warding and game sense.  

Lux is hard in laning phase with all her mana costs, but in teamfights? Its just throw your spells in the enemies general direction and watch them go boom.

I remember playing with Irelia Carries U on his smurf and he trashed his enemy laner and the enemy top's whole team was spamming "Report X, so bad, fed this irelia so hard" when obviously any plat V (think it was plat V elo at the time) would obviously lose to a challenger God tier irelia player.

People just want someone to blame when the game isn't going their way.
This seems to me like a great example of why smurfing should be a bannable offense.  At least 5 people had their games ruined and turned toxic so the smurf could have an easy win.

Thats silly to say it should be bannable, you can learn a lot playing against players who are much more skilled than you and its not like most high elo smurfs want to be in Plat, they just are trying to get through it so they can get to the higher elos.

Leaving aside the "probably a smurf" argument, I'd say your right that logic goes out the window. Not only that but the same mindset that leads to this unconstructive venting of anger probably also leads to despair and giving up.

In many cases "Who fed Zed?" and "Zed is fed. gg" might as well be the same. It's basically somebody saying, "This game is over."

If they had constructive intent, there'd be acknowledgment and advice rather than blame. For example, maybe after Zed got his second or third kill, say something like,
"Kat, just bunker down. Play safe and hold your turret even if you have to give up farm to do it. Let us know right away if he roams. We'll try to win or push the other lanes so we can get some help your way."

And then actually DO that. In the example given, if the rest of the team let Kat die nine times without offering constructive suggestions or trying to help her, it really was a team failure. Way too often, people have the attitude that if their teammates were doing their jobs, nobody would have to adapt their tactics to fix somebody else's mess. To that, I say "Tough. It's a tactical team game. Be flexible and work with what you have, or lose."

You hear people say  things like "too heavy" or 'can't carry trash". What are they actually doing to carry, though? Usually it's just doubling down and playing harder  at the same strategy that let the enemy team get an advantage in the first place. Knowing how to coach a weaker player through a tough lane is a lot easier, IMO, than trying to beat a fed opponent.
Giving other people advice on how to play never works, in my experience, because, no matter how polite or logical you are, people just do what they want, anyway.

I think it can work sometimes, but it is rarely worth it. There are basically 3 scenarios when you give advice to someone doing badly:

A. Person refuses to accept that they did something wrong. This player is likely to argue with you and/or get mad at you if you try to give them advice. No advice is going to be helpful with a player like this and you are at best wasting your time.

B. Person knows what they did wrong (especially when said thing is extremely obvious). You see this all the time with "stop feeding," "dont get blitz hooked" and so on. At best this kind of advice is useless (because anyone who has played this game to any degree realizes those things are bad) and at worst it can sound very condescending and flamey and make someone tilt worse.

C. Person doesn't know what they did wrong and is willing to accept your advice. So obviously in this case, advice can potentially be helpful. But you have to know exactly what they did wrong (which you won't always, as you aren't watching everything they are doing -- and chances are you aren't actually that much better than the people you are matched with anyway), AND exactly how to teach them to improve (which is harder than it sounds because many mistakes in league are more of a collection of small mistakes than one big easy one to fix). And even if all this is true, the exact situation that you taught them to play better in the future has to arise again in the same game for you to get any real benefit from all this trouble.

I think a policy of encouraging the feeder to keep trying and not tilt is far better. Accept whatever excuses they give (you can also make excuses for them -- "yeah man i hate that matchup so much" or "idk why their jungler keeps camping you when we are winning bot so hard") and never pressure them to admit blame. Give them a reason to keep playing (X lane is winning, better late game, better team comp, enemy team can always throw, etc.).

I agree so much.

Just a heads up to people who say this kind of thing thinking it makes them look less at fault for also contributing to the enemy kills, it doesn't. If you're just now starting to pay attention, then you're doing a pretty terrible job as well. Why would you go in and try to duel with someone who has more kills and gold than you? That's completely your fault if you do that and die or lose a significant chunk of your HP.

If they roam to your lane, and catch you while you're over extended with no vision, that's also your fault.

Part of being on a team is helping your teammates out. If a feast or famine champion like Yasuo has dug themselves a hole, telling them to "not feed" isn't constructive or helpful. Tell them that you are not neglecting their lane, and will be there to help them out once you're done with whatever you're doing. Let them know it's okay to lose a tower, or farm under the tower. Trying to shame someone is only going to make them lose all hope, and make it that much harder for them to make a comeback and be of help to you.

Most of the time when I see that asked it's not cut and dry like the example you posted. I had a game the other day where I was playing Mid lane Lux and I was up  1-0-1 against my lane opponent Zed who was 0-2-0. I pinged mia, went back to buy and when I came back he had 3 kills. I honestly had no idea where he got those from. I didn't say anything, but I certainly thought it.
Think it all you want. What is cut and dry is that the person actually typing it into chat is someone that has no business paying a team game.

Because by feeding 9 kills before midgame, you screwed everyone else trying to win.

Losing lane is one thing, no one is going to blame you for that. Repeatedly trying to 1v1 dive your enemy after they have gotten 3 kills over you is feeding. And it ruins the game for everyone else on your team.

Here's the thing: sometimes its not possible to play safe other than by leaving lane. Leaving lane against Zed is dangerous since he's AD and builds attack speed, meaning he'll just keep taking turrets. If Kat gets behind even 0-2, she can't be in the same lane as Zed anymore.

Giving up your outer turret is a perfectly reasonable response to losing lane.  Even Zed isn't safe trying to push your *inner* turret alone, that's way too far for him to get away if he gets collapsed on by your jungler and a roam from another lane.

Of course that lets him roam, so all your other lanes have to be careful, but if they actually ARE careful you can stop the bleeding.  Or feeding, as the case may be.
